Hi Charlie,

   I face the same problem before. I went through several stage of solution.

1. Modify the JUnit's all three test runner to init log4j and distribute 
  a internal version of JUnit.

2. Extending all three JUnit runner. Seems to be a lot of work for a 
simple job.

3. Currently, we are using AspectJ and keep the code of JUnit intact. 
The attached is a patched to JUnit 3.7.

It includes two new file:

i. A build.xml
ii. A log4j aspect

To build it, you need aspect 0.8b3 from www.aspectj.org and log4j jar 
files under lib dir.

David Li
DigitalSesame


chw@... wrote:

> Folks:
> 
> 
> We are just starting to use JUnit to support our development.  We have 
> a substantial collection of Log4j code in our system.  When we run a 
> JUnit test, the Log4j code complains that the system is not 
> initialized properly. 
> 
> We have put initialization in the main program of our test case, but 
> that does not seem to work.  We have moved the initialization code 
> into the setUp() function.  When run, the class loader complains about 
> this location. (We used the Java Swing runner)
> 
> Do I need to create a specialized TestRunner or is there a hook to get 
> log4j working under JUnit?
> 
> Thanks,
>
